title: Palgrave Darling Island logo
content:
Does anyone know if the typeface used for the Palgrave Identity or the ’darling island’ sample is a cutsom face or a commercially available font that I can purchase for a project?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [palgrave.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/typophile.com/files/palgrave.gif) | 6.44 KB |

 [‹ (x) Art Deco open face "Retail store" - Mona Lisa Recut {Mike F}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/typophile.com/node/13100 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Autodesk logo - (similar to) Vigor {Dav} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/typophile.com/node/13096 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Damien Mair

comments.content: ’ [Variable](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/www.madtype.net/variable.html)’, _by Matt Desmond, may be a commercially available alternate_..
Hey thanks for the suggestion. Im after a face that has a more human quality as per the sample. Variable is a little too mono spaced for the job in question.

It looks custom, especially since the two fonts don’t quite match.  
I think for palgrave they flipped the e over to make the a.

There are too many possibilities for similar ’techno’ fonts for me to be convinced yet that this is a custom font. I can believe that it is customized, like flipping the a/e letters, or using an upper case i for the l (’el’). I don’t think this is the font, but see how close [Leger (T-26)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/leger/regular/testdrive.html?s=paIgrave&p=48) would be if you flipped the a and used the u.c. i for the l.

- Mike Yanega
I meant customized, although it would have been extremely easy to create that logo from scratch. I wonder why they didn’t match the two fonts up.

Two more similar fonts: [Identikal Curvature](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/curvature/regular/testdrive.html?s=palgrave&p=48) and [House Chalet Comprimé](http://web.archive.org/web/20071208135240/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=11&subpage=viewfonts), especially the 1970 variant. The latter would only need a redesigned e to flip for the a, as Patty suggested.

- Mike Yanega

By the way, the a and e in palgrave are not the same letter flipped. The counter is a different shape.

- Mike Yanega
